title: FULL OUTER JOIN

theory.text:
1. What is a FULL OUTER JOIN?
A FULL OUTER JOIN combines the results of both a LEFT JOIN and a RIGHT JOIN. The result set will contain all rows from both tables. For rows where a match is found, the data from both tables is present. Where no match is found in either table, the missing side will have NULL values.

2. Why use a FULL OUTER JOIN?
It is essential when you need to see all the data from two tables, regardless of whether there is a match. This is very useful for data reconciliation tasks, such as finding all employees who have no department and all departments that have no employees in a single query.

3. How does it work?
Conceptually, it takes every row from the left table and every row from the right table and joins them based on the ON condition. If a row from one table doesn't find a match in the other, it's still included in the result, with NULLs in the columns of the table where it lacked a match.

4. What is the syntax?
The standard syntax is `SELECT ... FROM table1 FULL OUTER JOIN table2 ON table1.column = table2.column;`. However, since SQLite (the database used in this app) doesn't support this directly, it must be simulated.
To simulate a FULL OUTER JOIN in SQLite, you perform a LEFT JOIN and a RIGHT JOIN and combine their results using the UNION operator. This effectively merges all rows from both tables.

practice.title: Basic JOIN
practice.description: Write a basic JOIN query between two tables.
practice.starterCode:
-- Basic JOIN query
SELECT 
-- Columns from both tables
FROM table1
JOIN table2 ON 
-- Join condition
practice.solution: SELECT c.name, o.order_date FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id;
practice.hint: Use table aliases and specify the join condition with ON.
practice.expectedOutput: Combined data from both tables where the join condition matches.

practice.title: JOIN with WHERE
practice.description: Combine JOIN with WHERE clause for filtering.
practice.starterCode:
-- JOIN with filtering
SELECT 
-- Your columns
FROM table1 t1
JOIN table2 t2 ON 
-- Join condition
WHERE 
-- Filter condition
practice.solution: SELECT c.name, o.total FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id WHERE o.total > 100;
practice.hint: Add WHERE clause after the JOIN to filter the combined results.
practice.expectedOutput: Joined data that also meets the WHERE condition.

practice.title: Multiple JOINs
practice.description: Join three or more tables together.
practice.starterCode:
-- Multiple JOINs
SELECT 
-- Columns from multiple tables
FROM table1 t1
JOIN table2 t2 ON 
-- First join condition
JOIN table3 t3 ON 
-- Second join condition
practice.solution: SELECT c.name, o.order_date, p.product_name FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id JOIN products p ON o.product_id = p.product_id;
practice.hint: Chain multiple JOIN clauses, each with their own ON condition.
practice.expectedOutput: Data combined from all joined tables.

practice.title: Advanced JOIN Query
practice.description: Create a comprehensive JOIN query with aliases and filtering.
practice.starterCode:
-- Advanced JOIN query
SELECT 
-- Aliased columns
FROM 
-- Multiple tables with aliases and joins
WHERE 
-- Additional filtering
practice.solution: SELECT c.name AS customer_name, COUNT(o.order_id) AS order_count FROM customers c LEFT JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id GROUP BY c.customer_id, c.name;
practice.hint: Combine JOINs with GROUP BY and aggregate functions for advanced analysis.
practice.expectedOutput: Aggregated data showing relationships between tables.

steps.description: First, write a query to find all employees who do not have a department.
steps.solution: SELECT e.name FROM employees e LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.id WHERE d.id IS NULL;

steps.description: Next, write a query to find all departments that have no employees.
steps.solution: SELECT d.name FROM departments d LEFT JOIN employees e ON e.department_id = d.id WHERE e.id IS NULL;

steps.description: Write the first part of the simulated FULL JOIN: a LEFT JOIN from employees to departments.
steps.solution: SELECT e.name, d.name FROM employees e LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.id;

steps.description: Combine the first query with a second query using UNION to include departments that have no employees.
steps.solution: SELECT e.name, d.name FROM employees e LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.id UNION SELECT e.name, d.name FROM departments d LEFT JOIN employees e ON d.id = e.department_id;
